trans-unit.source: Connection assets in Azure Automation | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Connection assets in Azure Automation | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Connection assets in Azure Automation contain the information required to connect to an external service or application from a runbook. This article explains the details of connections and how to work with them in both textual and graphical authoring.
trans-unit.target: Connection assets in Azure Automation contain the information required to connect to an external service or application from a runbook. This article explains the details of connections and how to work with them in both textual and graphical authoring.

trans-unit.source: An Automation connection asset contains the information required to connect to an external service or application from a runbook.
trans-unit.target: An Automation connection asset contains the information required to connect to an external service or application from a runbook.

trans-unit.source: This may include information required for authentication such as a username and password in addition to connection information such as a URL or a port.
trans-unit.target: This may include information required for authentication such as a username and password in addition to connection information such as a URL or a port.

trans-unit.source: The value of a connection is keeping all of the properties for connecting to a particular application in one asset as opposed to creating multiple variables.
trans-unit.target: The value of a connection is keeping all of the properties for connecting to a particular application in one asset as opposed to creating multiple variables.

trans-unit.source: The user can edit the values for a connection in one place, and you can pass the name of a connection to a runbook in a single parameter.
trans-unit.target: The user can edit the values for a connection in one place, and you can pass the name of a connection to a runbook in a single parameter.

trans-unit.source: The properties for a connection can be accessed in the runbook with the Get-AutomationConnection activity.
trans-unit.target: The properties for a connection can be accessed in the runbook with the Get-AutomationConnection activity.

trans-unit.source: When you create a connection, you must specify a connection type.
trans-unit.target: When you create a connection, you must specify a connection type.

trans-unit.source: The connection type is a template that defines a set of properties.
trans-unit.target: The connection type is a template that defines a set of properties.

trans-unit.source: The connection defines values for each property defined in its connection type.
trans-unit.target: The connection defines values for each property defined in its connection type.

trans-unit.source: Connection types are added to Azure Automation in integration modules or created with the <linkText>Azure Automation API</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Connection types are added to Azure Automation in integration modules or created with the <linkText>Azure Automation API</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The only connection types that are available when you create a connection are those installed in your automation account.
trans-unit.target: The only connection types that are available when you create a connection are those installed in your automation account.

trans-unit.source: Secure assets in Azure Automation include credentials, certificates, connections, and encrypted variables.
trans-unit.target: Secure assets in Azure Automation include credentials, certificates, connections, and encrypted variables.

trans-unit.source: These assets are encrypted and stored in the Azure Automation using a unique key that is generated for each automation account.
trans-unit.target: These assets are encrypted and stored in the Azure Automation using a unique key that is generated for each automation account.

trans-unit.source: This key is encrypted by a master certificate and stored in Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: This key is encrypted by a master certificate and stored in Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: Before storing a secure asset, the key for the automation account is decrypted using the master certificate and then used to encrypt the asset.
trans-unit.target: Before storing a secure asset, the key for the automation account is decrypted using the master certificate and then used to encrypt the asset.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlets in the following table are used to create and manage Automation connections with Windows PowerShell They ship as part of the <linkText>Azure PowerShell module</linkText><title></title> which is available for use in Automation runbooks.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlets in the following table are used to create and manage Automation connections with Windows PowerShell They ship as part of the <linkText>Azure PowerShell module</linkText><title></title> which is available for use in Automation runbooks.

trans-unit.source: Cmdlet
trans-unit.target: Cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationConnection</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationConnection</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Retrieves a connection.
trans-unit.target: Retrieves a connection.

trans-unit.source: Includes a hashtable with the values of the connection’s fields.
trans-unit.target: Includes a hashtable with the values of the connection’s fields.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New-AzureAutomationConnection</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New-AzureAutomationConnection</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Creates a new connection.
trans-unit.target: Creates a new connection.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Remove-AzureAutomationConnection</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Remove-AzureAutomationConnection</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Remove an existing connection.
trans-unit.target: Remove an existing connection.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set-AzureAutomationConnectionFieldValue</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set-AzureAutomationConnectionFieldValue</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Sets the value of a particular field for an existing connection.
trans-unit.target: Sets the value of a particular field for an existing connection.

trans-unit.source: The activities in the following table are used to access connections in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: The activities in the following table are used to access connections in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: Activities
trans-unit.target: Activities

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Get-AutomationConnection
trans-unit.target: Get-AutomationConnection

trans-unit.source: Gets a connection to use in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: Gets a connection to use in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: Returns a hashtable with the properties of the connection.
trans-unit.target: Returns a hashtable with the properties of the connection.

trans-unit.source: You should avoid using variables in the –Name parameter of Get- AutomationConnection since this can complicate discovering dependencies between runbooks and connection assets at design time.
trans-unit.target: You should avoid using variables in the –Name parameter of Get- AutomationConnection since this can complicate discovering dependencies between runbooks and connection assets at design time.

trans-unit.source: From your automation account, click Assets at the top of the window.
trans-unit.target: From your automation account, click Assets at the top of the window.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the window, click Add Setting.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the window, click Add Setting.

trans-unit.source: Click Add Connection.
trans-unit.target: Click Add Connection.

trans-unit.source: In the Connection Type dropdown, select the type of connection you want to create.
trans-unit.target: In the Connection Type dropdown, select the type of connection you want to create.

trans-unit.source: The wizard will present the properties for that particular type.
trans-unit.target: The wizard will present the properties for that particular type.

trans-unit.source: Complete the wizard and click the checkbox to save the new connection.
trans-unit.target: Complete the wizard and click the checkbox to save the new connection.

trans-unit.source: From your automation account, click the Assets part to open the Assets blade.
trans-unit.target: From your automation account, click the Assets part to open the Assets blade.

trans-unit.source: Click the Connections part to open the Connections blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Connections part to open the Connections blade.

trans-unit.source: Click Add a connection at the top of the blade.
trans-unit.target: Click Add a connection at the top of the blade.

trans-unit.source: In the Type dropdown, select the type of connection you want to create.
trans-unit.target: In the Type dropdown, select the type of connection you want to create.

trans-unit.source: The form will present the properties for that particular type.
trans-unit.target: The form will present the properties for that particular type.

trans-unit.source: Complete the form and click Create to save the new connection.
trans-unit.target: Complete the form and click Create to save the new connection.

trans-unit.source: Create a new connection with Windows PowerShell using the <linkText>New-AzureAutomationConnection</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Create a new connection with Windows PowerShell using the <linkText>New-AzureAutomationConnection</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet has a parameter named ConnectionFieldValues that expects a hash table defining values for each of the properties defined by the connection type.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet has a parameter named ConnectionFieldValues that expects a hash table defining values for each of the properties defined by the connection type.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands create a new connection for <linkText>Twilio</linkText><title></title> which is a telephony service that allows you to send and receive text messages.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands create a new connection for <linkText>Twilio</linkText><title></title> which is a telephony service that allows you to send and receive text messages.

trans-unit.source: A sample integration module that includes a Twilio connection type is available in <linkText>Script Center</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: A sample integration module that includes a Twilio connection type is available in <linkText>Script Center</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This connection type defines properties for Account SID and Authorization Token, which are required to validate your account when connecting to Twilio.
trans-unit.target: This connection type defines properties for Account SID and Authorization Token, which are required to validate your account when connecting to Twilio.

trans-unit.source: You must <linkText>download this module</linkText><title></title> and install it in your automation account for this sample code to work.
trans-unit.target: You must <linkText>download this module</linkText><title></title> and install it in your automation account for this sample code to work.

trans-unit.source: You retrieve a connection in a runbook with the Get-AutomationConnection cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You retrieve a connection in a runbook with the Get-AutomationConnection cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This activity retrieves the values of the different fields in the connection and returns them as a <linkText>hash table</linkText><title></title> which can then be used with the appropriate commands in the runbook.
trans-unit.target: This activity retrieves the values of the different fields in the connection and returns them as a <linkText>hash table</linkText><title></title> which can then be used with the appropriate commands in the runbook.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to use the Twilio connection in the previous example to send a text message from a runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to use the Twilio connection in the previous example to send a text message from a runbook.

trans-unit.source: The Send-TwilioSMS activity used here has two parameter sets that each use a different method for authenticating to the Twilio service.
trans-unit.target: The Send-TwilioSMS activity used here has two parameter sets that each use a different method for authenticating to the Twilio service.

trans-unit.source: One uses a connection object and another uses individual parameters for the Account SID and Authorization Token.
trans-unit.target: One uses a connection object and another uses individual parameters for the Account SID and Authorization Token.

trans-unit.source: Both methods are shown in this sample.
trans-unit.target: Both methods are shown in this sample.

trans-unit.source: You add a Get-AutomationConnection activity to a graphical runbook by right-clicking on the connection in the Library pane of the graphical editor and selecting Add to canvas.
trans-unit.target: You add a Get-AutomationConnection activity to a graphical runbook by right-clicking on the connection in the Library pane of the graphical editor and selecting Add to canvas.

trans-unit.source: The following image shows an example of using a connection in a graphical runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows an example of using a connection in a graphical runbook.

trans-unit.source: This is the same example shown above for sending a text message using Twilio from a textual runbook.
trans-unit.target: This is the same example shown above for sending a text message using Twilio from a textual runbook.

trans-unit.source: This example uses the UseConnectionObject parameter set for the Send-TwilioSMS activity that uses a connection object for authentication to the service.
trans-unit.target: This example uses the UseConnectionObject parameter set for the Send-TwilioSMS activity that uses a connection object for authentication to the service.

trans-unit.source: A <linkText>pipeline link</linkText><title></title> is used here since the Connection parameter is expecting a single object.
trans-unit.target: A <linkText>pipeline link</linkText><title></title> is used here since the Connection parameter is expecting a single object.

trans-unit.source: The reason that a PowerShell expression is used for the value in the To parameter instead of a Constant value is that this parameter expects a string array value type so that you can send to multiple numbers.
trans-unit.target: The reason that a PowerShell expression is used for the value in the To parameter instead of a Constant value is that this parameter expects a string array value type so that you can send to multiple numbers.

trans-unit.source: A PowerShell expression allows you to provide a single value or an array.
trans-unit.target: A PowerShell expression allows you to provide a single value or an array.

trans-unit.source: The image below shows the same example as above but uses the SpecifyConnectionFields parameter set that expects the AccountSid and AuthToken parameters to be specified individually as opposed to using a connection object for authentication.
trans-unit.target: The image below shows the same example as above but uses the SpecifyConnectionFields parameter set that expects the AccountSid and AuthToken parameters to be specified individually as opposed to using a connection object for authentication.

trans-unit.source: In this case, fields of the connection are specified instead of the object itself.
trans-unit.target: In this case, fields of the connection are specified instead of the object itself.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Links in graphical authoring</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Links in graphical authoring</linkText><title></title>
